contentrichtext.text: [[File:Edward-Dannreuther.jpg|thumb|right|Dannreuther in the 1890s]] '''Edward Dannreuther''' (4 November 1844, [[Strasbourg]] – 12 February 1905, [[Hastings]]) was a German pianist and writer on music, resident from 1863 in England. In Dannreuther's youth his father had emigrated to [[Cincinnati]] in the US, and established a piano manufacturing business. Under pressure from his father to enter banking as a career, a prospect he found uncongenial, he escaped to [[Leipzig]] in 1859. He trained as a musician at the [[University of Music and Theatre Leipzig|Leipzig Conservatory]], where he was a pupil of [[Ignaz Moscheles]]. He became a champion of Wagner, and founded the London [[International Association of Wagner Societies|Wagner Society]] in 1872. In 1863 he had been recruited by [[Henry Chorley]] to perform in London at [[the Crystal Palace]] concerts. His performances of [[Chopin]] and [[Beethoven]] were well received; after his marriage in 1871 he decided to settle permanently in England. Dannreuther became a professor of piano at the [[Royal College of Music]] in 1895, a position he held until his death.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Dannreuther, Professor Edward|journal=Who's Who,|year=1905|volume=vol. 57|pages=p. 399|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=vDsJAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA399}}</ref> An enthusiast for new music, he was an important influence on the composer [[Hubert Parry]], who was his pupil.<ref name=dnb>Dibble, Jeremy, [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/35393 "Parry, Sir (Charles) Hubert Hastings, baronet (1848–1918)"], ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography,'' Oxford University Press, 2004, accessed 18 April 2013 {{ODNBsub}}</ref> A memorial plaque on his former home at 12 Orme Square, [[Westminster]], London was unveiled on 26 July 2005. <ref>[http://www.westminster.gov.uk/services/leisureandculture/greenplaques/ "Edward Danreuther"], City of Westminster green plaques</ref> His son [[Hubert Edward Dannreuther]] was a British admiral and one of six survivors of the sinking of [[HMS Invincible (1907)|HMS Invincible]]. == Sources == * ''The Harvard Biographical Dictionary of Music'', Harvard Univ. Press, 1996, ISBN 978-0-674-37299-3, S. 196 * Carl Dahlhaus, Hans Heinrich Eggebrecht (eds.): ''Brockhaus Riemann Musiklexikon'', 1. Band. Schott Mainz, Piper München, 3.
